column1: We moved westward about mid-afternoon over a rippled and sparkling summer sea; an enticing sea
column3: and apparently a welcome sea to all on board; it certainly was to me
column4: after the distressful dustings and smokings and swelterings of the past weeks. The voyage would furnish a three-weeks holiday
column5: with hardly a break in it. We had the whole Pacific Ocean in front of us
column6: with nothing to do but do nothing and be comfortable. The city of Victoria was twinkling dim in the deep heart of her smoke-cloud
column7: and getting ready to vanish and now we closed the field-glasses and sat down on our steamer chairs contented and at peace. But they went to wreck and ruin under us and brought us to shame before all the passengers. They had been furnished by the largest furniture-dealing house in Victoria
column8: and were worth a couple of farthings a dozen
column9: though they had cost us the price of honest chairs. In the Pacific and Indian Oceans one must still bring his own deck-chair on board or go without
column10: just as in the old forgotten Atlantic times—those Dark Ages of sea travel.
